In alignment with Theorem 1, the regularization parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda is chosen as Î»=Câ‹…Ïƒyâ‹…logâ¡(n+d)nğœ†â‹…ğ¶subscriptğœğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘›\lambda=C\cdot\sigma_{y}\cdot\sqrt{\frac{\log(n+d)}{n}}, where Cğ¶C is referred to as â€œpre-factorâ€ and Ïƒysubscriptğœğ‘¦\sigma_{y} is a
calibration factor depending on the distribution of the response. The calibration factor is chosen as an approximation of the expected standard deviation of the response variables {yi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}, where the expectation is taken with respect to the random predictors333This expectation is evaluated using numerical integration, approximating the linear predictor by a Nâ€‹(Î²0âˆ—,âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥22)ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ›½0superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½22N(\beta_{0}^{*},\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}^{2})-random variable justified by the central limit theorem.. The use of
Ïƒysubscriptğœğ‘¦\sigma_{y} is motivated by results on linear regression in [23] and an analysis of the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-estimation error for Î¾âˆ—superscriptğœ‰\xi^{*} if Î²âˆ—superscriptğ›½\beta^{*} were known (omitted for space reasons). In practice, Ïƒysubscriptğœğ‘¦\sigma_{y} can be approximated by taking the average of the variance function
of the corresponding GLM evaluated at the {yi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}; in order to enable Figure 2 that is specifically dedicated to the selection of Î»ğœ†\lambda, the factor Ïƒysubscriptğœğ‘¦\sigma_{y} is fixed so that it does not vary across different randomly generated data sets.

The above three approaches are evaluated in terms of their â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-estimation error for the
regression parameter, i.e., âˆ¥Î²estâˆ’Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½estsuperscriptğ›½2\lVert\beta^{\text{est}}-\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}, and the deviance (Kullback-Leibler divergence) between Î¼âˆ—=ğ„â¡[ğ²âˆ—|ğ±]superscriptğœ‡ğ„conditionalsuperscriptğ²ğ±\mu^{*}=\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}[\mathbf{y}^{*}|\mathbf{x}] and Î¼est=(hâ€‹(ğ±iâŠ¤â€‹Î²est))i=1nsuperscriptğœ‡estsuperscriptsubscriptâ„superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–topsuperscriptğ›½estğ‘–1ğ‘›\mu^{\text{est}}=\big{(}h(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top}\beta^{\text{est}})\big{)}_{i=1}^{n}, where we recall that hâ€‹(â‹…)â„â‹…h(\cdot) denotes
the response function in GLMs. The notation Î²estsuperscriptğ›½est\beta^{\text{est}} represents a placeholder for any of the three estimators introduced above. The results shown in Figures 2, 3, and 4 are averages over the 100 replications obtained for each setting.

Figure 2 confirms that as the pre-factor Cğ¶C increases, the error ratio approaches one as expected since Î¸^â†’Î¸^naiveâ†’^ğœƒsuperscript^ğœƒnaive\widehat{\theta}\rightarrow\widehat{\theta}^{\text{naive}} as Cğ¶C grows. Second, we note that the error ratio increases sharply beyond one as Câ†’0â†’ğ¶0C\rightarrow 0; this corresponds to a regime of overfitting. Note that as Câ†’0â†’ğ¶0C\rightarrow 0 the proposed approach effectively yields an over-parameterized model achieving perfect fit on a given data set. This in agreement with Theorem 1 which requires a lower bound on Î»ğœ†\lambda for its results to hold. Figure 2 indicates
that Câˆˆ[0.2,1]ğ¶0.21C\in[0.2,1] typically yields satisfactory results independent of the specific setting
or the specific distribution of the response variable.

Average estimation errors for the regression parameter are shown in Figure 3. Shaded areas are used to represent the error range the for the proposed approach in dependence of the pre-factor Cğ¶C: the upper and lower margins of the shaded areas represent the maximum and minimum error over Câˆˆ[0.1,2]ğ¶0.12C\in[0.1,2], while the dashed lines outside the shaded areas indicate
Â±plus-or-minus\pm5 Ã—\times standard error. Overall, Figure 3 shows that the proposed estimator
can achieve substantial improvements over the naive estimator in a variety of settings. The extent
of the improvement generally increases with the fraction of mismatches and the signal level as measured by âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}. For example, in the Poisson case the proposed approach with
optimally calibrated Î»ğœ†\lambda roughly achieves a three-fold reduction in average estimation error over the naive solution when âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2=1subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½21\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}=1, whereas a five-fold to six-fold reduction is achieved when âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2=2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½22\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}=2. Despite the improvements that are obtained, the performance of the proposed estimator is still somewhat far from the oracle, specifically as k/nğ‘˜ğ‘›k/n increases, which indicates a potential for further reductions in error.

The results shown in Figure 4 concerning the deviance between Î¼âˆ—superscriptğœ‡âˆ—\mu^{\ast} and Î¼estsuperscriptğœ‡est\mu^{\text{est}} as explained above agree with what is expected based on the results
for the estimation error in Figure 3. Again, the results indicate a dependence
of the improvement achieved by the proposed estimator on the signal level and the fraction of mismatches.

Binary response. We now address the case of binary logistic regression. Note that this case behaves differently
from the three distributions for the response considered above, including binomial response with a significant number of trials: it is clear that a massive number of samples is required in order to estimate Î²âˆ—superscriptğ›½\beta^{*} accurately from binary response if âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} is large; at the same time, if âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} is small, the separation between the two classes corresponding to the two values
of the response variable is weak and thus the inherent noise is scarcely distinguishable from mismatch error in the response variable, which amounts to what has been extensively studied in the machine learning literature under the terms â€œlabel noiseâ€ (e.g., [58]). For this reason, we adopt the simulation setup above with sufficiently strong signal, i.e., âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2âˆˆ{4,6,8}subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½2468\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}\in\{4,6,8\} while Î²0âˆ—=2superscriptsubscriptğ›½02\beta_{0}^{*}=2, but the three competitors are evaluated only in terms of the deviance between Î¼âˆ—superscriptğœ‡\mu^{*} and Î¼estsuperscriptğœ‡est\mu^{\text{est}}.
Figure 5 shows that the proposed approach achieves improvements over the naive estimator, but the improvements are less pronounced than for the three other settings. The observed moderate improvement is in alignment with what is reported in the paper
[44] that studies the empirical performance of the proposed estimator exclusively in the setting of binary response with noisy labels.

caption: Figure 6

Hamming distance between Ï€^â€‹(Î²âˆ—)^ğœ‹superscriptğ›½\widehat{\pi}(\beta^{*}) and Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} (on a log10(â‹…+Ïµ)\log_{10}(\cdot+\,\epsilon) scale with Ïµ=0.001italic-Ïµ0.001\epsilon=0.001), averaged over 1000 replications. Different curves correspond to different random design.
references:
In light of Theorem 3, permutation recovery
can be achieved if and only if âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} is large enough, and specifically for Poisson case, if in addition Î²0âˆ—/âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2superscriptsubscriptğ›½0subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½2\beta_{0}^{*}/\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} exceeds a certain threshold. Figure 6 confirms this qualitatively. In particular, we observe that the ratio Î²0âˆ—/âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2superscriptsubscriptğ›½0subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½2\beta_{0}^{*}/\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} is crucial in the Poisson case unlike the other cases. Furthermore, we note that the distribution of the design does not have a significant impact on the results: all three random design can achieve (at least approximate) permutation recovery given sufficient signal as quantified by âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½2\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}. Finally, note that for the Gamma distribution, recovery results improve as the shape parameter Î½ğœˆ\nu increases.

caption: Figure 7

Left: 2-D histogram of the response variable before and after linkage resulting based on 100 random permutations. Right: Scatterplots of the response variable before and after linkage for four selected permutations.
references: In order to mimic mismatch error introduced by record linkage, the response variable (count) is put into a separate file that additionally contains varying combinations of variables that are used for record linkage (see below for a list of those combinations). In order to enforce one-to-one linkage, ties between potentially matching records given the variables used for matching are broken uniformly at random; in order to account for that randomness, we consider 100 independent replications, and the results reported subsequently represent averages over those replications unless noted otherwise. Put differently, the underlying random permutations Î âˆ—superscriptÎ \Pi^{*} are of the block form Î âˆ—=bdiagâ€‹(Î 1âˆ—,â€¦,Î Kâˆ—)superscriptÎ bdiagsubscriptsuperscriptÎ 1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptÎ ğ¾\Pi^{*}=\text{bdiag}(\Pi^{*}_{1},\ldots,\Pi^{*}_{K}), where Kğ¾K denotes the number of unique combinations of values assumed for the matching variables. The average fraction of mismatches k/nğ‘˜ğ‘›k/n obtained in this way approximately equals 0.230.230.23. Figure 7 illustrates the discrepancy between actual response and response after linkage based on the following combination of matching variables: month, holiday, weekday, workingday, temp555temp denotes the temperature in degree Celsius on a given day (integer-valued).. In practice, the combination of variables used for matching may not be (fully) disclosed to the data analyst that operates on the merged data. Therefore, in addition to the case in which the matching variables are fully known, we also consider cases in which only one or two of the matching variables out of five overall are known (cf.Â Table 6).
